show.title: Pulp Fiction
show.headline: "You know what they call a Quarter Pounder with cheese in Paris?"

event.title: <show-title>Pulp Fiction</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Do the twist at our PULP FICTION Movie Party
event.description:
PULP FICTION shook audiences around the world when it first arrived 30 years ago, lifting elements from a wide array of time-worn stories and weaving them together into something truly new. Considering its impact on film history and just how damn watchable it is, any time is a great time to celebrate this iconic achievement.

When you arrive, we'll provide you with an “adrenaline” shot pen in case you need a shot to the heart, candy cigarettes (just pretend they're Red Apple band), and a yellow coffee mug so you can enjoy some "serious gourmet sh*t" just like Jules.

So don’t be a square, daddio. Grab your honey bunny and cruise on down to the most fun, most bloody, most groovy Movie Party in town.

show.title: Irresistible
show.headline: Jon Stewart returns to political comedy with his uproarious film IRRESISTIBLE

event.title: <show-title>Irresistible</show-title> <event-type-title>Free Victory Screening</event-type-title>
event.headline: See Jon Stewart's uproarious political comedy for free & get out the vote
event.description: The only thing better than seeing a hilarious comedy expertly skewering our modern democratic process is actually participating in it. That’s why we’re teaming up with the Raleigh League of Women Voters for a FREE screening of Jon Stewart’s outrageous satire, IRRESISTIBLE. Not only will you see a fantastic film, but you’ll also learn all about how to register to vote to make your voice heard in your community and across the country. All you have to do to save your seat is purchase a fully refundable food and beverage voucher redeemable at the show.

eventType.title: Free Victory Screening
eventType.headline: Our way of saying thank you to our Victory Members
eventType.description: Calling all Victory Members! We’re saying thanks with a free screening. Just buy a food & beverage voucher to reserve your seat, and then use it toward food and drink at the show.

titleCardImage.altText: Free Victory Screening Art Card

show.title: The Crow (1994)
show.headline: In a world without justice, he was chosen to protect the innocent

event.title: <show-title>The Crow (1994)</show-title>
event.headline: In a world without justice, he was chosen to protect the innocent
event.description: Brandon Lee (son of Bruce) was supposed to be a star. In what would have been his big breakout role, Lee stars as rocker Eric Draven - a man brutally murdered only to be resurrected as a supernatural avatar of vengeance. Based on the cult comic book and directed by Alex Proyas (DARK CITY), THE CROW is a gothic superhero smorgasbord of sights and sounds. When Lee was killed in an on-set accident during the making of the film, THE CROW also became an everlasting tribute to his undeniable screen presence.

show.title: On Cinema at the Cinema Special
show.headline: We've got the Oscar Fever. Hope you got it too.

show.title: Happy Gilmore
show.headline: Adam Sandler doesn't play golf. He destroys it.

event.title: <show-title>Happy Gilmore</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Just tap it in at the happiest movie party we've ever thrown
event.description:
Grab your grandma’s clubs and join us at an interactive screening celebrating the only guy to ever take his skates off and try to stab somebody – HAPPY GILMORE. He was the likable, rage-fueled everyman we needed to take on the Shooter McGavins of the world, winning tournaments and our hearts with one mighty swing of his club. It’s easily one of Adam Sandler’s funniest, most quotable movies ever (and that’s saying something), and if you disagree, you’re welcome to a warm glass of shut-the-hell-up.

Will there be interactive fun and themed props? Did Grizzly Adamas have a beard? He did, and you can definitely count on a memorable time with foam hockey sticks, golf tees, and golf ball lip balm. Bonus points if you wear your gold jacket.

show.title: Labyrinth
show.headline: The beloved '80s puppet fantasy film

event.title: <show-title>Labyrinth</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Party, movie party all night long
event.description:
What could possibly be more magical than watching this iconic ‘80s fantasy conjured by Jim Henson, George Lucas, and David Bowie at the peak of their powers on the big screen? Feeling it come truly alive at an interactive screening with fellow fans.

With themed props like shiny stress balls to roll around in your hand, masquerade masks, mini hands, and orange balloons, it’s the next best thing to Jareth the Goblin King actually showing up at your bedroom window.

titleCardImage.altText: Movie Party TC

show.title: The Twilight Saga: Eclipse
show.headline: It all begins...with a choice

event.title: <show-title>The Twilight Saga: Eclipse</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Do us an extraordinary honor and say yes to this interactive screening
event.description:
Every choice has its consequences, some more than others. For example, if you choose to join us for another interactive TWILIGHT screening, the consequence will be you having an incredible time at the movies.

We’re back for another Movie Party in the perpetually cloudy town of Forks, and we think this one will ECLIPSE all the rest. Edward’s back in town and Bella has a few big decisions to make. Will she go for the muscled-up werewolf she’s known since they were kids, or the immortal 17-year-old asking for her hand in marriage? Either way, we’ve got some themed props that you’re sure to imprint on, including custom-packaged hand warmers (in case you need to hide out on a snowy mountain), moon keychains, and Bella’s engagement ring (note: it will be a slightly less valuable recreation).

So book those seats before all the shows get filled with armies of newborns – we promise we won’t steal your reason for existing.

eventType.title: Movie Party
eventType.headline: Celebrate your fave movies with fun, interactive props, themed drinks, and more

titleCardImage.altText: Movie Party TC

show.title: The Twilight Saga: New Moon
show.headline: The next chapter begins

event.title: <show-title>The Twilight Saga: New Moon</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Say hello to Jacob's biceps in this lovesick interactive screening
event.description:
No need to throw yourself off a cliff hoping to get a glimpse of Movie Party fun, because we’re back from Italy with another interactive TWILIGHT screening.

It’s a whole NEW MOON this time around. Edward’s gone, Jacob hit puberty in a big way, and Bella has a serious case of separation anxiety. The only thing that hasn’t changed is how much fun you’ll have. You give us everything we need just by breathing, but we’re giving all of you some themed gifts like BWTHHYBL bumper stickers, mini desk calendars, and custom bandaids. Be sure to keep that last one handy for papercuts at family gatherings.

So whether you’re Team Edward or Team Jacob, hop on your motorcycle and join us for another adventure in Forks that’s...kind of beautiful.

titleCardImage.altText: Movie Party TC

show.title: Gummo
show.headline: A primordial dose of Gen X apathy.

event.title: <show-title>Gummo</show-title>
event.headline: A primordial dose of Gen X apathy.
event.description:
The directorial debut of enfant terrible-turned-EDGLRD Harmony Korine, GUMMO stands as one of the defining art blasts of the 1990s. We follow the citizens of Xenia, Ohio (led by KIDS standout Chloë Sevigny and OUT OF THE BLUE's Linda Manz) as they circle the drain in a suburban wasteland. With a soundtrack featuring Bathory, Burzum and Eyehategod - GUMMO defies the trends of the decade at every turn and will make sure you never eat in the bathtub the same way again.

35mm print courtesy of Park Circus.

show.title: A/V Geeks Present: Those Excruciating 1980s
show.headline: An evening of 16mm delights 'n' frights

show.title: Argylle
show.headline: Things get hairy for an author & her cat when her spy novel becomes reality

show.title: Blue Giant
show.headline: A young man is determined to become one of the greatest jazz musicians

show.title: The House of the Devil
show.headline: Talk on the phone. Finish your homework. Watch TV. DIE!

event.title: <show-title>The House of the Devil</show-title>
event.headline: Talk on the phone. Finish your homework. Watch TV. DIE!
event.description: Ti West’s THE HOUSE OF THE DEVIL very well may be the greatest horror film of its decade. The film is a slow-burning occult shocker, plotted with an emphasis on suspense and shot to recreate the glory days of ‘80s horror. Where some throwback films feel plastic and phony (and, at their worst, self-parodying), THE HOUSE OF THE DEVIL hits the nail firmly on the head – it works. West’s script and direction operate together to bring the characters to a boil, resulting in a third act that will paralyze you. Starring Jocelin Donahue (INSIDIOUS: CHAPTER TWO), Tom Noonan (THE MONSTER SQUAD), Mary Woronov (ROCK 'N' ROLL HIGH SCHOOL), AJ Bowen (YOU'RE NEXT), and a beautiful Greta Gerwig, just before she started to make it in Hollywood (in hip huggers!).

show.title: Nimona
show.headline: A shapeshifting creature helps a knight who is trained to destroy her

show.title: The Mask (1994)
show.headline: From zero to hero

event.title: <show-title>The Mask (1994)</show-title>
event.headline: “S-ssss-ssss-sssss-smokin'!”
event.description:
Men. YIKES. Throw a weird mask on a man? EVEN WORSE. Sorry. Let me start over. It’s part two of Queer Film Theory 101’s journey into the dark psyche of the '90s American male with the cartoonish and absurd 1994 classic THE MASK (all caps feel appropriate) staring one of our favorite fractured masculinity clowns, Jim Carrey, and featuring the amazing debut of Cameron Diaz. Just like a be-dragged Bugs Bunny seducing Elmer Fudd, THE MASK is surprisingly queer when you think about it. THE MASK is giving chaos bisexual by way of Tex Avery.

Stanly Ipkiss, a hapless bank employee and certified “nice guy,” happens upon an ancient mask of indeterminant and likely problematically racist origin. When he pops it on his wormy little mug, he’s suddenly transformed into the uncomfortably horny anti-hero THE MASK! Is this new persona just the ticket that Stanley needs to assert himself and win the affection of the sultrily Jessica Rabbit-coded Tina? Or will the unbridled and violent masculinity of his new alter-ego cause him to lose everything…perhaps even his life?

Chuck Russell’s adaptation of Doug Mahnke and John Arcudi’s much darker Dark Horse Comic series became one of the top-grossing films of 1994. Due to the success of THE MASK, ACE VENTURA: PET DETECTIVE, and DUMB AND DUMBER (all released in 1994), Jim Carrey became a household name, and millions of children across the world became a little more annoying. C’mon, you remember running around yelling, “Somebody stop me!” at anyone who would listen, right? What a nightmare. (Micheal Foulk)

show.title: American Psycho
show.headline: From the controversial best-seller by Bret Easton Ellis

event.title: <show-title>American Psycho</show-title>
event.headline: 4K restoration of Mary Harron’s brilliant horrorshow
event.description:
Directed by Mary Harron and co-written by co-star Guinevere Turner, this brilliant adaptation of Bret Easton Ellis's controversial novel is one of the most exceptional horror films of the 21st century. During the Christmas season in the late 1980s, yuppie weirdo Patrick Bateman (Christian “Batman” Bale) is surrounded by people he hates and a culture he can't stand. With nowhere else to turn, Bateman embraces his inner serial killer and embarks on a chainsaw-fueled rampage. Functioning as both a hilarious middle finger to male toxicity and a subversive horror-party, AMERICAN PSYCHO is the most "fun" you'll ever have while seeing Jared Leto get a hatchet to the face.

Content warning: This movie features the use of slurs and the death of a dog.

Screening the 4K restoration

show.title: Blade
show.headline: Part man. Part vampire. All hero.

event.title: <show-title>Blade</show-title>
event.headline: Wesley Snipes slays as the ultimate vampire hunter.
event.description:
Vampires and superhero movies are a dime-a-dozen these days. But are they cool? Wesley Snipes' titular day walker does two things: kill the undead and look cool while doing it. And, honestly, that may be all you need for pulp bliss. Thankfully, the pre-Y2K cyber-goth sheen delivered by British commercial whiz Stephen Norrington also brings the goods as a stylish action/horror blast. Come for a blood-rave, stay for an ice-skating lesson. XOXO, Blade. (Jake Isgar)

4k DCP courtesy of Warner Bros.

eventType.title: Special Event

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Carnival of Souls
show.headline: The ground-breaking surrealist chiller

event.title: <show-title>Carnival of Souls</show-title>
event.headline: The ground-breaking surrealist chiller
event.description:
Very few regional horror movies are strong enough to be considered miracles. But CARNIVAL OF SOULS is a miracle beyond miracles. After a mysterious car accident, Mary (Candace Hilligoss) takes a job as a church organist. Subsequently, she finds herself tormented by a mysterious ghoul...and his undead friends. Shot in Lawrence, Kansas, and at Utah's majestic Saltair Pavilion by industrial filmmaker Herk Harvey, CARNIVAL OF SOULS is like nothing else on the planet. With its stunning black and white photography and ghostly organ score, this eerie, thoughtful dreamscape influenced everything from George Romero’s NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD to David Lynch’s ERASERHEAD. Prepare to have your skeleton rattled. (Joseph A. Ziemba)

DCP courtesy of Janus Films

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Cure
show.headline: Murder without memories

event.title: <show-title>Cure</show-title>
event.headline: Kiyoshi Kurosawa’s masterful nerve-chilling thriller
event.description:
Presented in Japanese with English subtitles

Kiyoshi Kurosawa’s spellbinding international breakthrough established him as one of the leaders of the emerging new wave of Japanese horror while pushing the genre into uncharted realms of philosophical and existential exploration. A string of shocking, seemingly unmotivated murders – each committed by a different person yet bearing the same grisly hallmarks – leads Detective Kenichi Takabe (Koji Yakusho) into a labyrinthine investigation to discover what connects them, and into a disturbing game of cat and mouse with an enigmatic amnesiac (Masato Hagiwara) who may be evil incarnate. Awash in a mood of hushed, hypnotic dread, CURE is a tour de force of psychological tension and a hallucinatory journey into the darkest recesses of the human mind.

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Gremlins 2: The New Batch
show.headline: The most joyful monster bash of 1990

event.title: <show-title>Gremlins 2: The New Batch</show-title>
event.headline: The most joyful monster bash of 1990
event.description:
This movie is a work of art. Joe Dante’s long-awaited sequel to the beloved GREMLINS is an unhinged spectacle that finds Billy (Zach Galligan), Kate (Phoebe Cates), and the adorable Gizmo taking a front-row seat for the murderous beasties' takeover of an NYC highrise. Stuffed to the gills with sublime monster effects that rival John Carpenter’s THE THING, hyperblast gags that feel like they escaped from a deranged Looney Tunes cartoon, and relentless chaos, GREMLINS 2: THE NEW BATCH is sheer joy. This is the exact movie that you’d hope to see after watching the viral Key & Peele sketch that reimagined the project’s wild origins. And we’re forever grateful for that.

Screening an archival 35mm print

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Mirror Mirror (1990)
show.headline: Marina Sargenti’s teen horror triumph

event.title: <show-title>Mirror Mirror (1990)</show-title>
event.headline: Marina Sargenti’s teen horror triumph
event.description:
Before THE CRAFT, there was MIRROR MIRROR. Co-written by sisters Annette and Gina Cascone and directed by Marina Sargenti, the film follows high school goth Megan (Rainbow Harvest, a dead ringer for Winona Ryder’s Lydia Deetz character in BEETLEJUICE) as she deals with typical teenage stuff: crushes, bullies, and a haunted mirror that grants her supernatural powers. MIRROR MIRROR combines YA vibes straight out of a Christopher Pike novel with plenty of R-rated thrills. But the film’s most notable – and enjoyable – aspect is its nuanced portrayal of relationships between women, which was rare for the horror genre in 1990.

Screening the restoration

show.title: The Bird with the Crystal Plumage
show.headline: Argento's stylish mystery reinvents the thriller

landscapeHeroImage.altText: THE BIRD WITH THE CRYSTAL PLUMAGE

portraitHeroImage.altText: THE BIRD WITH THE CRYSTAL PLUMAGE

posterImages.altText: THE BIRD WITH THE CRYSTAL PLUMAGE

event.title: <show-title>The Bird with the Crystal Plumage</show-title>
event.headline: Argento's stylish mystery reinvents the thriller
event.description:
"Its scares are on a much more basic level than, say, a thriller by Hitchcock. It works by exploiting our fear of the dark." – Roger Ebert

In 1970, Dario Argento (DEEP RED, SUSPIRIA) indelibly redefined the “giallo” genre of murder-mystery thrillers with THE BIRD WITH THE CRYSTAL PLUMAGE – a mind-bending mix of murder, obsession, and art. A staggeringly assured first feature, this film establishes the key traits that define Argento’s filmography, including lavish visuals and a flare for wildly inventive and brutal scenes of violence. With sumptuous cinematography by Vittorio Storaro (APOCALYPSE NOW) and a seductive Ennio Morricone score, this landmark film has never looked better in this 4K restoration.

Restoration via Arrow Video; DCP via the American Genre Film Archive

show.title: I Know Who Killed Me
show.headline: Lindsay Lohan is a woman in trouble in this infamous American giallo

landscapeHeroImage.altText: Lindsay Lohan in I Know Who Killed Me

portraitHeroImage.altText: Lindsay Lohan in I Know Who Killed Me

posterImages.altText: Ww i know who killed me poster

event.title: <show-title>I Know Who Killed Me</show-title>
event.headline: Lindsay Lohan is a woman in trouble in this infamous American giallo
event.description:
The trajectory of a child star is usually a tragic one, but whether by design or accident, Lindsay Lohan cemented her place as a savior of trash cinema from the new millennium when she starred in this heavy-handed story of dismemberment, torture, and fully clothed stripteases. LiLo stars as a wholesome high school student who's really into writing. She goes missing, and another Lindsay Lohan shows up who's a stripper from a broken home. Are they the same person? A ridiculous use of red and blue color schemes for the two Lindsays suggests something more mysterious is afoot. Then bad Lindsay starts mysteriously losing limbs (rather than consult a doctor, she searches Ask.com). I KNOW WHO KILLED ME is like a script Brian De Palma threw out for being too obvious, directed by David Lynch's dirt-cheap equivalent. In other words, it's really stupid fun, and it looks great!

35mm print courtesy of Sony Pictures Repertory.

show.title: Mac and Me
show.headline: An alien trying to escape from NASA is befriended by a wheelchair-bound boy

event.title: <show-title>Mac and Me</show-title>
event.headline: Brought to you by McDonald's.
event.description:
A blatant E.T. imitation, MAC AND ME spilled onto Earth eight years after Spielberg's beloved creature, capturing zero hearts and conjuring no one's tears. Yet it found life as an amusing object, in no small part due to Paul Rudd's insistence on showing one particular clip on Late Night with Conan O'Brien. While we'd refrain from encouraging mean-hearted laughter at such a misguided movie, there is much glee to be found in the oddness of MAC AND ME. Those crazy-looking Mysterious Alien Creatures! A five-minute dance scene in McDonald's! And instead of Elliott on a bicycle, we get earnest little Eric on the run with MAC in his wheelchair!

35mm print courtesy of Park Circus.

show.title: Popeye
show.headline: Robin Williams brings the spinach-loving sailor to life!

event.title: <show-title>Popeye</show-title>
event.headline: The comic strip marvel from ... Robert Altman ?!
event.description:
In no universe did anyone anticipate a cantankerous genius like Robert Altman to adapt a comic strip into a full-tilt musical, let alone one that we deserve. A co-production between Paramount and Disney with a ramshackle set constructed on isle of Malta, POPEYE's marriage of pop-art and poetic realism creates a rare dose of confectionary splendor. Rootin' n' tootin' sailor Popeye (Robin Williams in his film debut) washes ashore in the town of Sweethaven, falls in love with Olive Oyl (a never-better Shelley Duvall), and engages in all sorts of bare-knuckle adventures. Composed by rock god Harry Nilsson, POPEYE is the type of creative gamble that must be seen (and seen again) to believe.

DCP courtesy of Paramount Pictures.

show.title: Samurai Cop
show.headline: The L.A. cop vs. Yakuza action trasherpiece.

event.title: <show-title>Samurai Cop</show-title>
event.headline: The L.A. cop vs. Yakuza action trasherpiece.
event.description:
In the late 1980s, direct-to-video trash-action was as common as shoulder pads and skinny ties. But even in this neon-soaked jungle, SAMURAI COP was a true anomaly. Living legend Joe Bob Briggs said it best, "A recently unearthed, soon-to-be-classic kung-fu action-comedy skin flick with gratuitous gore elements." That's a great start, but there's so much more. Ex-Sylvester Stallone bodyguard Matt Hannon stars as Joe Marshall, a tank of a man who will do literally whatever it takes to bring down the late Robert Z'Dar and the sadistic Katana gang – even if it means destroying dozens of innocent lives in the process. SAMURAI COP is one of the most rampaging crowd-pleasers to ever be gifted to the universe

DCP courtesy of the American Genre Film Archive.

show.title: Terminal USA + I Was a Teenage Serial Killer Double Feature
show.headline: A double dose of '90s American underground provocations

landscapeHeroImage.altText: TERMINAL USA + I WAS A TEENAGE SERIAL KILLER Double Feature

portraitHeroImage.altText: TERMINAL USA + I WAS A TEENAGE SERIAL KILLER Double Feature

posterImages.altText: TERMINAL USA + I WAS A TEENAGE SERIAL KILLER Double Feature

event.title: <show-title>Terminal USA + I Was a Teenage Serial Killer Double Feature</show-title>
event.headline: A double dose of '90s American underground provocations
event.description:
In TERMINAL USA, Holly (Jenny Woo), Marvin (director Jon Moritsugu), and Katzumi (Moritsugu again) are average Asian-American teenage siblings with not-so-average predilections for backstabbing, kinky sex, and drug-fueled freakouts. Neglected by their parents, the kids turn to outside “help” (including the scene-stealing Amy Davis, Moritsugu’s wife and longtime collaborator) in order to escape their bored existence. Naturally, this leads to gore killings, sex tapes, and the most hilarious phone conversations ever captured on 16mm film. A candy-colored hellscape that feels like an episode of STRANGERS WITH CANDY that was filmed by Dario Argento during a three-day acid bender, Moritsugu's TERMINAL USA is a crucial piece of 1990s alternative cinema – smart, shocking, and one of the most deranged films to ever be funded by American taxpayers. This is the film HEATHERS wished it could be. (AGFA)

I WAS A TEENAGE SERIAL KILLER is SLACKER meets Valerie Solanas, as a 19-year-old woman responds to catcalls, condescension, and bad sex the only way she knows how: murder. Taking on every major function from production through distribution, Sarah Jacobson proved herself as a shit-kicker and rule-breaker, finding fans in filmmakers Allison Anders (GAS FOOD LODGING) and Tamra Davis (CROSSROADS), as well as Kim Gordon of Sonic Youth. (AGFA)

show.title: The Devil Conspiracy
show.headline: The most slept-on fantasy spectacle of the last year.

event.title: <show-title>The Devil Conspiracy</show-title>
event.headline: The most slept-on fantasy spectacle of the last year.
event.description: What if John Carpenter and Dan Brown adapted a Hellblazer comic? A puzzling combination, but that's part of the strange alchemy of THE DEVIL CONSPIRACY. An atheist art historian comes face-to-face with the forces of darkness, as a Satanic cult steals the Shroud of Turin to bring about the birth of the Antichrist. How will they do this, you ask? With the power of genetics, of course! Oh, and the Archangel Michael descends to Earth to slam evil with both holy fists. Imbued with the wonder and spectacle of a dozen Marvel Cinematic Universe entries, THE DEVIL CONSPIRACY is an earnest blast of fantasy and spectacle that can turn even the faintest of heart into a true believer. (Jake Isgar)

show.title: The Rare Blue Apes of Cannibal Isle
show.headline: Newly-uncovered kindertrauma that must be seen to be believed.

event.title: <show-title>The Rare Blue Apes of Cannibal Isle</show-title>
event.headline: Newly-uncovered kindertrauma that must be seen to be believed.
event.description:
When a young boy decides to run away from home with his beloved pet duck Mr. Quack Quack, the two find themselves lost in a strange world filled with singing anthropomorphic blue apes and cannibal crocodiles, deadly booby traps, and psychedelic hellscapes. Shot in Malaysia by veteran sexploitation filmmaker Donn Greer (101 ACTS OF LOVE), THE RARE BLUE APES OF CANNIBAL ISLE is a singularly bizarre "kid's film" that's ready to inspire nightmares yet again after being lost for nearly 50 years.

DCP courtesy of Vinegar Syndrome and the American Genre Film Archive.

show.title: Under the Cherry Moon
show.headline: Prince's screwball romance set on the French Riviera.

event.title: <show-title>Under the Cherry Moon</show-title>
event.headline: Prince's romantic ode to Classic Hollywood.
event.description:
True fans of Prince know that UNDER THE CHERRY MOON has been unjustly maligned. In PURPLE RAIN we see his tortured side, with a glimpse of his playfulness. Well, CHERRY MOON is Prince in full-on playful mode, flirting not only with the characters but with us, the audience. You will blush when you see him in the bathtub, you will grin with glee at each new outfit, you will be charmed as he tries to get Kristin Scott Thomas to say “Wrecka Stow”. Prince directed this movie, a companion piece to his Parade album, so you know it’s gotta be him through and through!

35mm print courtesy of Park Circus.

event.title: <show-title>Kung Fu Panda 4</show-title> <event-type-title>Family Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Party like a dragon warrior
event.description: How can you possibly make KUNG FU PANDA 4 even more fun? Add games, crafts, and fun props for the whole family at our Family Party screening. Skadoosh! Walk the warrior’s path with kung fu headbands, chopsticks, LED dragon puppets, and crafting your very own paper lanterns. Plus, all that fun is easily the best way to find inner peace. Your ticket includes the movie, the activities, and the props. Be sure to arrive up to 30 minutes early to give yourself plenty of time to get in on the fun.

show.title: Brain Damage
show.headline: Frank Henenlotter’s hallucinogenic creature feature

event.title: <show-title>Brain Damage</show-title>
event.headline: Frank Henenlotter’s hallucinogenic creature feature
event.description:
After making horror history with BASKET CASE and FRANKENHOOKER, the incomparable Frank Henenlotter unleashed BRAIN DAMAGE—the ultimate Grimm’s Fairy Tale for adults. This slimy slice-of-NYC-life follows a poor schmo who is addicted to a drug called Aylmer. But unlike heroin or cocaine, Aylmer is a mutant penis monster who needs human brains to survive. BRAIN DAMAGE is hilarious, unsettling, and jam-packed with bad taste gags that would make John Waters blush. Fifteen stars.

Uncut restoration courtesy Arrow Films and the American Genre Film Archive.

show.title: Possession (1981)
show.headline: A mind-bending psychosexual fever dream

event.title: <show-title>Possession (1981)</show-title>
event.headline: A mind-bending psychosexual fever dream
event.description: Something is wrong with Anna (Isabelle Adjani). Having taken a lover, she abruptly asks her husband, Mark (Sam Neill), for divorce. He's desperate for an explanation, but Anna's answers are elusive at best. She's in crisis – becoming emotional, avoidant, self-harming, and neglectful of their son. Mark has no idea, but behind her increasingly erratic behavior is a monstrous secret. The films of Andrej Zulawski lie beyond narrative, emotion, and sanity. POSSESSION is a raw depiction of the monstrosity of marital strife and the fear of female sexuality. An arthouse favorite combining existential dread with doppelgangers, blood, and body horror, POSSESSION is truly one of a kind.

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

marketStrings.value: The personal closed captioning device displays feature film dialogue and other audio in the form of English-language text for individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing.

The descriptive audio headset provides individuals who are blind or have low vision with an English-language narration of the details of the feature presentation that can't be understood by the soundtrack alone.

Upon request at the box office, we provide assistive listening headsets with amplified audio for those individuals who are hard of hearing. For guests who prefer to use their own hearing aids, neck loops, or cochlear implants, our assistive listening headsets have a 3.5mm headphone jack to connect to those devices.

In order to ensure the highest quality experience for all guests, you may not enter a movie after it has started. We’d love to see you up to 30 minutes early. Running late? No worries, we will happily exchange your ticket for a different showtime or a raincheck to a future show.

sessionAttributes.name: All Ages
sessionAttributes.description: Get ready for maximum family fun! Our All Ages screenings include pre-show activity sheets and crayons, a relaxed noise policy, and kids menus. All ages welcome with a parent or guardian.

sessionAttributes.name: Kid Friendly
sessionAttributes.description: Grab the fam and let the fun begin! Our Kid Friendly screenings include pre-show activity sheets and crayons, a relaxed noise policy, and kids menus. Ages 3+ welcome with a parent or guardian.

sessionAttributes.name: Sensory Friendly
sessionAttributes.description: Our all-inclusive screenings welcome babies, infants, nursing moms, and guests with Autism and other sensory needs. Sound will be quieter. Theater will be a little less dark. Chatter, walking around, and babies being babies are A-OK.
